content.webTitle: West Ham’s Mark Noble says chances of Euro 2016 England call are ‘very slim’

fields.headline: West Ham’s Mark Noble says chances of Euro 2016 England call are ‘very slim’
fields.bodyText: Having been overlooked by Roy Hodgson again, at least Mark Noble is in good company with another West Ham United stalwart. Billy Bonds was a permanent fixture in a claret and blue shirt for 21 years, never won an England cap and was forced to withdraw with a rare injury on one occasion when he did receive a call-up. “He only played about 850 games for West Ham, so I’m not surprised he was injured,” Noble said, when the Bonds comparison was put to him while he was promoting his testimonial, which takes place at Upton Park on Monday. Slaven Bilic, cannot understand why Hodgson has decided not to give Noble a chance in England’s upcoming friendlies against Germany and Holland but West Ham’s captain was in too much of a good mood to indulge in any score settling. Long accustomed to the disappointment of not getting the call when England squads are announced, the midfielder is 29 in May and he knows his latest omission means he should probably forget about going to Euro 2016, even though he has been in the form of his life this season. “I’d love to but I think especially with the squad announcement, if I’m honest with myself, the chances are very slim,” Noble said. “Once the squad got announced, I just put it to the back of my mind. “There are some great players in that England squad and a lot of people, and West Ham fans thought I should have been in it but I’m not that sort of person. Obviously, over the last two months there has been so much talk about it and everyone I talk to asks me about it but I just took it in my stride – if it happened it happened and it would have been a nice problem to have. But it didn’t work that way and I can thoroughly look forward to Monday now. “I’m English, I’ve always wanted to play for England but it’s out of my hands. I’ve loved playing this season, it’s been a great season for me personally and for the club. But there is nothing I can do about England, I’ll just put it to the back of my mind and enjoy Monday with my family and my friends, and have a real good laugh.” Noble, who will donate the proceeds from his testimonial – current West Ham squad members not involved in internationals versus a West Ham All-Stars XI – to three charities, Help for Heroes, the Dylan Tombides Foundation and Richard House Children’s Hospice, has not spoken to Hodgson. “It’s not a personality thing because I’ve started every season under every manager at West Ham since I’ve been here,” Noble said. “I’ve played under Alan Pardew, Gianfranco Zola, Avram Grant, Sam Allardyce, Alan Curbishley and Slaven’s made me captain. I don’t think I’m a bad egg. At the end of the day it’s the manager’s decision. Everyone’s got their opinions. So be it. I’ve put it behind me now and I’m just going to enjoy the next couple of months.” His figures were a little off. Bonds played a record 793 times for West Ham and Noble, who made his 376th appearance for his boyhood club in last weekend’s 2-2 draw with Chelsea, has some catching up to do. With West Ham chasing a place in the Champions League and their first FA Cup triumph since 1980, England are the least of his concerns.
